message: Having a ton of web experience already (mostly mod_perl), I got up to speed enough to build simple apps in about a week.  Probably took about 6 months before I felt I was building things at the same speed as before, i.e. not having to constantly reference the docs.

Python? Maybe a year or two coming from a background of C and Perl, before I felt comfortable with stuff like metaclass and how the object model works. Maybe another year after that before I felt comfortable with the internals of CPython, enough to go codediving for answers anyway. Django took me maybe a month to learn the external stuff, still wouldn't call myself proficient in the guts though (the ORM code still confuses me).

I learned Python by learning Django, and I'd say it took a few months before I felt comfortable, but I was still learning a lot for the next year and a half.  I still learn new things about Python/Django that I didn't know, and have more to learn still.
Yeah I know that, I meant proficient no need to be humble about it lol
@ericflo Absolutely, I learn something new every week or so about both.

I think it depends on what your goals are as well. Most people can be productive within days or weeks depending on prior experience with web frameworks and OOP-like languages. Becoming proficient at developing low volume sites with a handful of features will take a few months. For larger, more complex sites I'd say being proficient demands a lot more expertise which is only going to come with putting in the time and learning from mistakes. I don't know if you'd call that "expert" but FWIW I know that if I tried to run with code I was writing back when I first would have considered myself proficient on the projects I work on now there would be disasters.
We had a few devs here come up to speed on Django (all were experienced in C) in about 3 weeks to the point that they could write new apps from scratch and not make a total mess of it.
@coderanger is a tight framework, and good ones prevent TOTAL messups hehe.

@convy Code is code, Python gives you plenty of space to write bad code. I've seen more than one C-style for loop in programmer tests submitted here. Writing good, idiomatic Python takes a little bit of time at least.
